\#\#\# User: Does it mean that my battery will "lose capacity" over the years (months?) or that it will just uncharge faster because it's consuming more energy?

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/dvOWA.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/dvOWA.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Batteries are consumable and have a finite lifetime, so you get the longest life if you can postpone the time it takes to get to 1000 full discharge and charge cycles. Most Macs will never reach that design goal in 3\-4 years except if you exhaust the charge daily. 

* [https://support.apple.com/en\-us/HT201585](https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201585)

If you need to always run hot, then you can probably afford $150 every 1000 cycles so it’s NBD but Apple likely wants to be sure you question the need for that setting to blaze through power at the high consumption rate with the powerful GPU engaged. 

Hopefully it’s obvious you empty your tank faster from full to empty as well when you tick that option.

Question: A MacBook user frequently uses high-performance settings that engage the powerful GPU. What is the most likely long-term consequence of this behavior on the laptop's battery?

A) The battery will maintain its capacity but discharge faster due to increased energy consumption.
B) The battery's capacity will decrease more rapidly over time, potentially requiring replacement within 3-4 years.
C) The battery's performance will improve over time as it adapts to the high-performance usage patterns.
D) The battery will maintain its capacity indefinitely as long as it's regularly fully discharged and recharged.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The documentation states that batteries are consumable with a finite lifetime, and their capacity decreases over time, especially with heavy use. Using high-performance settings that engage the powerful GPU will lead to faster battery consumption, accelerating the rate at which the battery reaches its maximum cycle count (around 1000 full discharge and charge cycles). This behavior is likely to cause the battery's capacity to decrease more rapidly, potentially necessitating a replacement within 3-4 years of heavy use. Options A, C, and D are incorrect as they don't accurately reflect the battery's long-term behavior under such conditions as described in the documentation.

\#\#\# User: I've recently got a new **black** iPhone 4S, but in iTunes and Xcode organizer it is shown as **white** (see screenshots below). 

I purchased this new within the UK (model MD239B), but I'm not sure if it was refurbished. [The search request](http://support.apple.com/kb/index?page=search&src=support_site.kbase.search&locale=en_GB&q=MD239B) says it is a white one. Could it possibly be a refurbished device? I've checked the serial number on support.apple.com, there is no single word similar to 'refurbished'.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/MiU5i.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: iTunes deduces the color of the iPhone from the serial number he finds on the logic board. For example:

```
MD269LL   = Black AT&T 64GB 4S  
MD271LL   = White AT&T 64GB 4S  
MD277LL/A = White Verizon 16GB 4S
...

```

So, check your model number and look it up to make sure you've got a black one.

![](https://i.stack.imgur.com/hpuwt.png)

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A customer purchased a black iPhone 4S, but notices that iTunes and Xcode organizer display it as white. What is the most likely explanation for this discrepancy?

A) The phone is a refurbished model that was originally white but had its exterior changed to black
B) There is a software glitch in iTunes and Xcode that randomly assigns colors to devices
C) The serial number on the logic board corresponds to a white iPhone model
D) The customer accidentally purchased a white iPhone with a black case

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The documentation indicates that iTunes and Xcode determine the color of the iPhone based on the serial number found on the logic board. Each serial number corresponds to a specific model and color combination. In this case, even though the phone appears black externally, the serial number likely corresponds to a white iPhone model. This could happen if there was a mismatch during manufacturing or if the logic board was replaced with one from a white model. The correct color display in iTunes and Xcode is based on this serial number, not the actual exterior color of the device.

Option B allows the 'waypoints' property to accept the entire 'address' array, regardless of how many elements it contains, making it the most flexible and correct solution for handling a variable number of waypoints.

\#\#\# User: Let $C\_d$ be a unit edge\-length cube in $d$ dimensions.
I would like to orient it ("tilt" it) so that the vertical (last) coordinates
of its $2^d$ vertices are maximally separated, in the sense
that the minimum vertical distance between any two vertices is maximized
over all orientations.

For $C\_2$ (in standard orientation, edges parallel to
Cartesian axes), tilting $\\arctan \\frac{1}{2} \\approx 26\.6^\\circ$ separates
the vertices by $\\delta\=1/\\sqrt{5} \\approx 0\.447$:

---

![](https://i.stack.imgur.com/63MLg.jpg)

---

For $C\_3$ (in standard orientation), I believe that rotating the vector $(0,0,1\)$ to lie on
the vector $(\\frac{1}{4},\\frac{1}{2},1\)$ results in a vertex separation of $\\delta\=1/\\sqrt{21} \\approx 0\.218$:

---

![](https://i.stack.imgur.com/HicKE.jpg)

---

My question is:

> **Q**. What is the generalization to $C\_d$ for $d\>3$? What is the largest
>  vertex separation $\\delta$ achievable?
>  Can one always achieve a uniform vertex separation
>  (the same $\\delta$ between each vertically adjacent pair),
>  as in $C\_2$ and $C\_3$?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Given a unit vector $u \\in \\mathbb R^d$, the "heights" of vertices of the $n$\-cube where $u$ is regarded as the vertical direction are the sums of subsets of the entries of $u$. Thus the minimum separation is the minimum difference
between the sums of two distinct subsets of these entries. If you take 
$$u \= \[1,2,\\ldots,2^{d\-1}]/\\sqrt{1^2 \+ 2^2 \+ \\ldots (2^{d\-1})^2} \= \\sqrt{\\dfrac{3}{4^d\-1}}\[1,2,\\ldots,2^{d\-1}]$$
you get uniform separation of $\\sqrt{3/(4^d\-1\)}$.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-part exam question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider a d-dimensional unit cube Cd. When oriented to maximize the minimum vertical separation between vertices, the separation δ is given by √(3/(4^d-1)). For a 5-dimensional cube C5, calculate:

1) The exact value of δ
2) The components of the unit vector u that achieves this separation
3) The angle (in degrees, rounded to 2 decimal places) between this u and the standard basis vector e5 = (0,0,0,0,1)

A) 1) δ = √(3/1023) ≈ 0.0543
   2) u = (1/√341)(1, 2, 4, 8, 16)
   3) 74.21°

B) 1) δ = √(3/1024) ≈ 0.0541
   2) u = (1/√341)(1, 2, 4, 8, 16)
   3) 73.90°

C) 1) δ = √(3/1023) ≈ 0.0543
   2) u = (1/√341)(1, 2, 4, 8, 16)
   3) 73.90°

D) 1) δ = √(3/1024) ≈ 0.0541
   2) u = (1/√340)(1, 2, 4, 8, 16)
   3) 74.21°

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
1) For d=5, δ = √(3/(4^5-1)) = √(3/1023) ≈ 0.0543
2) The vector u is given by √(3/(4^d-1))[1,2,...,2^(d-1)]. For d=5, this becomes:
   √(3/1023)[1,2,4,8,16] = (1/√341)(1,2,4,8,16)
3) To find the angle, we calculate the dot product of u with e5:
   u • e5 = 16/√341
   cos(θ) = 16/√341
   θ = arccos(16/√341) ≈ 73.90°

Option C is the only one that has all three parts correct.

\#\#\# User: While I was playing Minecraft hunger games, a silverfish attacked me. I started to fight it, but more kept on spawning. Is this a bug? How can I stop it? I already tried killing the silverfish but more spawn after it.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **No, this is not a bug. It is an intentional feature.** (though I've never seen it in Hunger Games before)

In Minecraft, there are "bug blocks" accessible in the creative inventory. They look exactly like stone bricks (or a variation of), stone, or cobblestone. These blocks are called ID's similar to "Stone Brick Monster Egg."

Silverfish have a special property \- when they get hit, they summon more. They can only summon more from these bug blocks, destroying the block in the process\*. If left alone, a silverfish will disappear into a non\-bug stone, cobble or stone brick block and turn it into a bug block. 

Whenever devious map makers want to cause chaos, they often spawn in a silverfish and surround it with bug blocks. Apparently the Hunger Games map had bug blocks, and you attacking the silverfish summoned more. 

\*Bug blocks also summon silverfish when broken by the player.

You can **prevent a horde of silverfish** by:

* **One hitting the silverfish**. Silverfish which are one\-hitted (killed in one strike with a weapon) don't summon more, even if there are bug blocks around.
* **Not digging bug blocks**. When you try to dig a bug block, it will dig sort of slow compared to a pickaxe, but quite quickly compared to the fist. It is a unique digging speed, meaning it can't be reproduced with a pickaxe \- so experienced players can tell if they are digging a bug block.
* **Running**. Though it might be obvious, as with most any other slower\-than\-player mob your best chance of survival is running.

5.answer:

A) Quickly break all nearby stone blocks to remove potential hiding spots
B) Use a low-damage weapon to slowly weaken the silverfish
C) Kill the silverfish with a single, powerful strike
D) Place water around the area to slow down the silverfish

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most effective strategy to prevent a horde of silverfish from spawning is to kill the initial silverfish with a single, powerful strike. According to the documentation, "Silverfish which are one-hitted (killed in one strike with a weapon) don't summon more, even if there are bug blocks around." This method prevents the silverfish from triggering the spawning mechanism.

Option A is incorrect because breaking nearby blocks could actually trigger more silverfish to spawn if they are "bug blocks."

Option B is incorrect because using a low-damage weapon would give the silverfish multiple opportunities to summon more of its kind.

Option D, while creative, is not mentioned in the documentation as an effective strategy and would not prevent the spawning mechanism.

\#\#\# User: Let $f : \\mathbb{R} \\to \\mathbb{R}$ such that the $k^{\\rm th}$ derivative of $f$ is strictly positive for every $x \\in \\mathbb{R}$. Define the forward difference operator to be:

$$\\Delta(g,h) \= g(x\+h) \- g(x),$$

and for $h\_1, \\ldots , h\_k \> 0$, 

$$\\Delta(g, h\_1, \\ldots , h\_k) \= \\Delta( \\Delta(g , h\_1 , \\ldots , h\_{k\-1}), h\_k).$$

Is it true that for all $x \\in \\mathbb{R}$ $$\\Delta(f , h\_1 , \\ldots , h\_k)(x) \> 0?$$

For $k \= 2$ this is true by convexity. I would like to have a reliable reference for this if it is true. If it is not true, is it true when $h\_1 \= \\ldots \= h\_k$? 

Any relevant information would be much appreciated, even if you feel it is only indirectly related, please leave a comment!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes, this is true. For the function $\\Delta(f,h)$ its $(k\-1\)$\-st derivative is strictly positive, since by Lagrange theorem it equals $$f^{(k\-1\)}(x\+h)\-f^{(k\-1\)}(x)\=hf^{(k)}(x\+\\theta h)\>0,$$ for some $\\theta\\in (0,1\)$. Then induct on $k$.

6.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Let f : ℝ → ℝ be a function such that its k-th derivative f^(k) is strictly positive for all x ∈ ℝ and all k ≥ 1. Define the forward difference operator Δ(g,h) = g(x+h) - g(x), and for h₁, ..., hₖ > 0, Δ(g, h₁, ..., hₖ) = Δ(Δ(g, h₁, ..., hₖ₋₁), hₖ). Which of the following statements is true?

A) Δ(f, h₁, ..., hₖ)(x) > 0 for all x ∈ ℝ and all k ≥ 1, but only when h₁ = h₂ = ... = hₖ.

B) Δ(f, h₁, ..., hₖ)(x) > 0 for all x ∈ ℝ and all k ≥ 1, regardless of the values of h₁, ..., hₖ, as long as they are positive.

C) Δ(f, h₁, ..., hₖ)(x) > 0 for all x ∈ ℝ, but only for k ≤ 2 due to convexity.

D) The positivity of Δ(f, h₁, ..., hₖ)(x) cannot be determined without additional information about the specific function f.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. This can be proven by induction on k. For k = 1, Δ(f, h₁)(x) = f(x+h₁) - f(x) > 0 because f' is strictly positive everywhere. Assume the statement is true for k-1. For k, we can consider Δ(f, h₁, ..., hₖ) as Δ(g, hₖ) where g = Δ(f, h₁, ..., hₖ₋₁). By the induction hypothesis, g'(x) > 0 for all x. Therefore, Δ(g, hₖ)(x) = g(x+hₖ) - g(x) > 0 by the mean value theorem. This holds for any positive values of h₁, ..., hₖ, not just when they're equal. Options A and C are too restrictive, while D underestimates what can be deduced from the given information.

\#\#\# User: I did some research on this and came across MEMS sensors, there were quite a lot of them, but most of them acted as a gyroscope which would give output for left\-right front\-back tilts. I want an inertia sensor that can detect sudden change in speed, as in case of an accident, and have a lower sensitivity so that it doesn't trigger on potholes, etc.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Strange you didn't find them since there are *way* more MEMS accelerometers than gyroscopes around.

Really, it's the same technology only tuned for linear acceleration instead of angular ones. Usually 1 axis (only in one direction) or 3 axes. Often you find 6 axes units (accelerometer \+ gyro) and even 9 axes ones (typical for phones: accelerometer \+ gyro \+ flux gates, gives the magnetic north)

As for sensitivity you'll want a *lower* sensitivity since a pothole gives a lot less Gs than a front collision :D Anyway, it's only a measurement range issue: you can buy 1G sensor for small vibration and, say, 16G sensor for detecting drops to ground. No idea of how many Gs is a car accident.

The output these days is often some kind of digital interface like I2C or SPI; there are however some analog output ones around if you prefer that.

Deciding if it's a collision or a pothole is a filtering issue usually delegated to software.

7.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An automotive engineer is designing an accident detection system for a new car model. Which of the following sensor configurations would be most appropriate for accurately detecting a collision while minimizing false positives from road conditions?

A) A single-axis MEMS gyroscope with high sensitivity, configured to detect sudden changes in angular velocity
B) A 3-axis MEMS accelerometer with a measurement range of ±16G, connected via I2C interface, with software filtering
C) A 9-axis sensor unit (accelerometer, gyroscope, and magnetometer) with analog output and no filtering
D) A 1-axis MEMS accelerometer with a measurement range of ±1G and SPI interface

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
B is the correct answer because:
1. A 3-axis accelerometer can detect sudden changes in speed in all directions, which is crucial for collision detection.
2. The ±16G range is appropriate for detecting high-impact events like collisions while not being overly sensitive to minor disturbances.
3. The I2C interface allows for digital communication with the car's computer system.
4. Software filtering is mentioned as the usual method to distinguish between collisions and potholes.

A is incorrect because a gyroscope primarily detects angular motion, not linear acceleration, which is more relevant for collision detection.

C is incorrect because while a 9-axis sensor provides more data, it's unnecessarily complex for this application. The analog output would require additional processing, and the lack of filtering could lead to false positives.

D is incorrect because a 1-axis accelerometer would only detect motion in one direction, missing potential collisions from other angles. The ±1G range is too low for collision detection and more suitable for detecting small vibrations.

\#\#\# User: I saw a bad answer in the queue, voted it down and got \-1 rep. Is this the expected behaviour of this site? If yes, what is the point of reviewing?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes, it is.

Downvoting an answer costs you \-1 rep, regardless of whether you got there via a review queue or by any other means. It helps to encourage reviewers to "spend" their downvotes wisely.

If that bothers you, you can avoid downvoting — you can still leave comments explaining what is wrong, etc.

Note also that if the answer is ultimately deleted, you get the rep points back anyway.

8.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: According to the StackExchange documentation, what are the consequences and considerations for downvoting an answer in a review queue?

A) Downvoting in a review queue doesn't affect reputation, but downvoting outside the queue costs -1 reputation.
B) Downvoting always costs -1 reputation, but the reviewer gains +1 reputation for participating in the review process.
C) Downvoting costs -1 reputation regardless of how the answer was encountered, and this reputation is only returned if the answer is ultimately deleted.
D) Reviewers are not allowed to downvote in review queues to maintain objectivity, they can only leave comments.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The documentation clearly states that downvoting an answer costs -1 reputation, regardless of whether it was encountered in a review queue or by any other means. This policy is in place to encourage reviewers to use their downvotes judiciously. The documentation also mentions that if the downvoted answer is eventually deleted, the reviewer gets their reputation point back. 

Option A is incorrect because the reputation cost applies both in and out of the review queue. Option B is wrong as there's no mention of gaining reputation for participating in reviews. Option D is false because reviewers are allowed to downvote in queues, though they have the alternative of leaving comments without downvoting if they prefer.

\#\#\# User: Whenever I am trying to eject my external hard drive I am getting "`Problem Ejecting USB Mass Storage Device`" alert and it is not allowing me to eject the device safely.

(System : Windows 10 21H1 Build 19043\.1081\)

[![img_eject](https://i.stack.imgur.com/wOej1.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/wOej1.png)

So, I open the **Event Viewer**, look for the `225 Event ID`, and found `System with process id 4` is preventing the hard disk from eject.

[![img_pid_4](https://i.stack.imgur.com/4N86O.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/4N86O.png)

When I looked at the `process id 4`, using **Process Explorer**, found 3 processes running under the System causing the problem. (`Interrupts, smss.exe, and Memory Compression`). The problem is, killing those processes wouldn't work as they are part of the System process, and also it is not recommended to do so.

[![img_process_explorer](https://i.stack.imgur.com/SIkpb.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/SIkpb.png)

I looked at Microsoft community posts, they are saying a bunch of different things, from killing the process from task manager, disabling windows defender, uninstalling device driver to changing disk removal policy (Quick to better performance) yada, yada.. sadly none of them working. At this moment the best thing I can do, shut down the machine and remove the device but it is not the optimal solution...

Does anybody know, how to make it work?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The one and only thing that is working for me \- Setting the External device to **Offline mode** from the **Disk Management** and set it back to **Online mode** when needed.

[![img_Management](https://i.stack.imgur.com/qzBRh.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/qzBRh.png)

(However one issue I have noticed, If the device contains Windows System Image/Backup and if it is set to Offline mode, Windows is not recognising the device when it comes to the System Image Recovery process until I boot into Windows and set the device to the Online mode. Maybe it's happening only in my case, but it's worth mentioning)

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A user is experiencing difficulties safely ejecting an external hard drive on Windows 10. After investigating, they discover that process ID 4 (System) is preventing the disk from being ejected. Which of the following solutions is most likely to resolve the issue without risking system stability or data loss?

A) Kill the processes listed under System (Interrupts, smss.exe, and Memory Compression) using Process Explorer
B) Disable Windows Defender and uninstall the device driver
C) Change the disk removal policy from Quick removal to Better performance
D) Set the external device to Offline mode in Disk Management, then set it back to Online mode when needed

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect and potentially dangerous, as killing system processes can lead to system instability or crashes.
Option B is not recommended and unlikely to solve the issue, as it reduces system security and may cause driver-related problems.
Option C is a common suggestion but, according to the user's experience, did not resolve the problem.
Option D is the correct answer, as it was reported to be the "one and only thing" that worked for the user. This method temporarily disconnects the drive from the system, allowing for safe removal, and can be reversed when the drive needs to be used again. While it has a minor drawback related to System Image Recovery, it remains the safest and most effective solution among the given options.

> 
> Wireless: 802\.11 a/b/g/n/ac

Step to reproduce the crash :
-----------------------------

1. turn wifi on (sometimes crashes happened just after deactivating wifi and when the systems restarted the wifi card had disappeared, icon marked with a cross and popup saying "no wifi hardware detected")
2. disconnect any ethernet thunderbolt cable or deactivate ethernet connexion
3. simply use the computer for instance navigating with safari or chrome or wait a little doing nothing (less than 2 minutes now, but it used to be hours before the problem occurs)
4. Boom ! Black screen, fans and keyboards back lights increase activity for a few seconds and then the computer just turns off completely

### Noticeable informations :

* bluetooth can be on or off, it doesn't matter or affect the crash
behavior even if sometimes when I turn on the computer after a crash
bluetooth can be activated or deactivated when it was in the opposite
state before the crash,
* no crashes occur when connected to internet with both wifi and ethernet or just through the ethernet port only. The problem is only when the wifi is on.
* no crashes when in the mac is started in safe mode and with only wifi on
* the issue started after updating to sierra os x and prior that date I had very few crashes in years (almost none). Unfortunately my time machine copies before migrating to sierra have been overwritten with post sierra's copies

### I have tried several solutions but the problem remains. Here is a list of the opérations I went through so far with absolutely zero success :

* Changing Mac OS X Wireless Card Country Code as explained [here](https://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/9768/change-mac-os-x-wireless-card-country-code)
* removing all wifi preferences and all extensions, LaunchAgents, LaunchDeamons, Internet pluggins, etc. (both in /Libbrary/, \~/Library/, /System/Library, etc.)
* removing all my applications that could mess up with the system (brew, ports, cleaner, magicPrefs, Citrix, antivirus, etc.) and cleaned all their remaining files (such as .plist files, etc.)
* updating to os x sierra with the utilities of the recovery mode
* bootable usb key, hard drive format, os x sierra clean installation and personal data recovery with time machine
* and of course I have tried contacting the apple support (feedback/bug report messages, phone calls and several visits to the so called genius bar where all hardware tests showed nothing wrong (their conclusion : as it works fine in safe mode, it might be a software issue but they don't know where and why turning wifi on is triggering the crashes). My conviction : it is a faulty sierra wifi card driver responsible of the crashes as I always get com.apple.driver.AirPort.Brcm4360\.0 crash logs after each single unwanted shutdown and few times accompanied with a com.apple.iokit.IO80211Family crash log (CCIOReporter log file).

I think all is said about my issue. And I will also provide a crash report (pretty messy) or an etreCheck reports (clearer) but both didn't give usable information. I hope my approach can help some of you solving similar issues and also that some can help me find a solution.

\#\#\# Top Answer: What helped me:

* Using OS X Mavericks (default OS for my laptop, didn't have a chance to use Sierra/ElCapitan)
* Using any usb wifi adapter;
* Using native wifi but power adapter is connected
* Using native wifi on battery but it should be charged \> 45%

What didn't help:

* OS reinstall (with/without disk formatting)
* Remove wifi, airport etc config files
* Reset SMC
* Reset NVRAM
* Look for updates (no updates available)

What I did else:

* Launched Apple Hardware test (OK)
* Launched some apple benchmarks (Geekbench 4, Blackmagic Disk speed test) (all OK)
* Launched Coconut Battery (got 7193 mAh, designed 8440 mAh)

Other problems I found:

* Can't turn the mac on (or wake it up) when the battery is low than 40%. But if I don't shut it down or hibernate it works down to 0%

I have no proofs but I think the problem is in the combination of soft wifi and battery status.

Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: A MacBook Pro user is experiencing frequent crashes when using WiFi. Based on the troubleshooting steps and observations, which of the following is most likely to resolve the issue?

A) Performing a clean install of macOS Sierra
B) Using the laptop while connected to a power adapter
C) Resetting the NVRAM and SMC
D) Removing all WiFi preference files

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The user reported that using the native WiFi while the power adapter is connected helped prevent crashes. This suggests that the issue may be related to power management or battery status affecting the WiFi hardware. Clean installs, resetting NVRAM/SMC, and removing preference files were attempted but did not resolve the problem. Using the laptop while plugged in appears to be the most effective workaround based on the information provided.

\#\#\# User: Is there a way to "sort" the points of a MultiLineString such that they follow a more sequential order? Let me illustrate what I mean with a graphical example:

Input
-----

Suppose I have the following MultiLineString: `MULTILINESTRING ((120 105, 140 98),(160 103, 140 98),(100 100, 120 105))`
[![Input MultiLineString](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZqZne.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZqZne.png)

Note how, to our human eyes, it seems out of order: the first (orange) segment is in the middle, the second (green) segment is coded backwards in relation to the other segments (i.e., pointing to the left instead of to the right).

Desired Output
--------------

The desired output would be the following LineString: `LINESTRING (100 100, 120 105, 140 98 160 103)`

[![Output LineString](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZRVbQ.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZRVbQ.png)

Note how the output is now looks much more sensible. It's one continuous `LineString`, the segments are all nicely ordered from left to right and the green segment itself is now oriented from left to right.

Is there a simple way to perform this kind of "reordering" inside `MultiLineString`s?

What I've done so far
---------------------

I'm trying to develop a solution using Python's `Shapely` library. My approach has two different steps:

* Extract unique coordinates
* Sort unique coordinates

I've been able to do the first part quite easily, but it's not clear to me how to reorder the points.

I thought about a heuristic that would find the point that is cumulatively furthest to all other points, label that as the starting point, add all other points to a pool of unsorted points and then sequentially find the next closest point until I run out of unsorted points.

However, this sorting heuristic would fail in A BUNCH of cases: consider a geometry that describes a spiral. Or a strong zig\-zagging pattern. Or a geometry with a bunch of self\-intersections. This heuristic would just fail completely.

Therefore, I suspect this approach of extracting unique points and sorting them isn't the right one.

Back to the start
-----------------

So, I'm back to my main question: how can I sort the coordinates of a `MultiLineString` such that they make more intuitive sense?

Reproducible example and code
-----------------------------

Here's the Python code for my very incomplete solution thus far.

```py
import shapely

# Write the MultiLineString WKT
mls_wkt = 'MULTILINESTRING ((120 105, 140 98),(160 103, 140 98),(100 100, 120 105))'

# Generate the shapely geometry
mls = shapely.wkt.loads(mls_wkt)

# Function that extracts unique coordinate values
def get_unique_points(input_multilinestring):
    # Gets a nested list of coordinates
    coords_nested = [list(this_geom.coords) for this_geom in input_multilinestring.geoms]

    # Flattens the list
    coords = [item for sub_list in coords_nested for item in sub_list]

    # Gets only the unique coords
    coords_set = set()
    coords_final = []
    for i,coord in enumerate(coords):
        if coord not in coords_set:
            coords_set.add(coord)
            coords_final.append(coord)
    return coords_final

```

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You might be able to just use [`shapely.ops.linemerge`](https://shapely.readthedocs.io/en/stable/manual.html#shapely.ops.linemerge). I haven't used it much, and cannot speak to how it handles potential floating point differences where the geometries in the MultiLineString meet.

```py
from shapely import wkt
from shapely.ops import linemerge

mls = wkt.loads('MULTILINESTRING ((120 105, 140 98),(160 103, 140 98),(100 100, 120 105))')

line_string = linemerge(mls.geoms)
# LINESTRING (100 100, 120 105, 140 98, 160 103)

```

13.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: When working with a MultiLineString in Python using Shapely, which of the following methods is most appropriate for converting it into a single, ordered LineString?

A) Extract unique coordinates from the MultiLineString and sort them based on their x-coordinate values
B) Use a custom heuristic to find the furthest point and sequentially add the closest points
C) Apply the shapely.ops.linemerge function to the MultiLineString's geometries
D) Manually reorder the segments of the MultiLineString based on their starting coordinates

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because simply sorting coordinates based on x-values doesn't account for the actual connectivity of line segments and could produce incorrect results for complex shapes.

Option B, while creative, is flawed as it would fail for many geometric configurations like spirals or zig-zag patterns, as mentioned in the original post.

Option C is the correct answer. The shapely.ops.linemerge function is specifically designed to merge the geometries of a MultiLineString into a single, ordered LineString, which is exactly what the question is asking for.

Option D is incorrect because manually reordering segments would be tedious, error-prone, and wouldn't necessarily produce the correct result for all cases.

The linemerge function handles the complexities of connecting line segments and ordering them appropriately, making it the most suitable solution for this problem.

\#\#\# Top Answer: Commenting out your entries in `/etc/fstab` for swap partitions allowed your computer to boot properly, albeit without a swap partition.

At some point in time, you may have had an encrypted swap partition. Then somebody tried to set it to use a regular unencrypted swap partition.

Since you know how to use gparted and blkid, I'll give you the short answer on how to get your swap partition back.

1. start gparted and delete your old encrypted sda9 partition
2. use gparted to recreate a new swap partition in the same (now unallocated) space. If you have 4G total RAM, you can create a slightly smaller swap partition than the 8G partition that you have before. Make it 4G.
3. select the newly created swap partition and right\-click on it and select the swapon command. This will temporarily enable swap.
4. in terminal, type `sudo blkid` and note the UUID for the newly created swap partition (it may, or may not, be sda9\).
5. in terminal, `sudo gedit -H /etc/fstab` and find the commented out line 

```
#UUID=2238a8ba-5029-47d6-8276-472f1bea530e none swap sw 0 0

```

remove the \#, and change the UUIID to the one that you got from the `blkid` command. Save and quit gedit.
6. reboot, and confirm that a `swapon` command properly shows your swap enabled.

Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: A user is experiencing boot issues with their dual-boot Windows 10 and Ubuntu 16.04 system. The system enters Emergency Mode and fails to mount the swap partition. After investigating, it's determined that the swap partition was previously encrypted. What is the correct sequence of steps to resolve this issue and restore proper swap functionality?

A) Delete the old swap partition, create a new unencrypted swap partition, enable swap temporarily, update /etc/fstab with the new UUID, and reboot.

B) Uncomment the cryptswap line in /etc/fstab, reformat the swap partition as encrypted, update the UUID, and reboot.

C) Use fsck to repair the existing swap partition, update /etc/fstab to use the repaired partition, and reboot.

D) Delete the swap partition entirely, remove all swap-related entries from /etc/fstab, and configure the system to use a swap file instead of a partition.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: The correct approach is to delete the old encrypted swap partition and create a new unencrypted one. This involves using gparted to delete the old partition and create a new swap partition in the same space. Then, the swap should be temporarily enabled using the swapon command. The UUID of the new partition should be obtained using blkid and used to update the /etc/fstab file, replacing the old UUID. Finally, a reboot will ensure the changes take effect and the swap is properly enabled. This sequence addresses the root cause of the problem (the encrypted swap) and sets up a fresh, unencrypted swap partition that should work correctly with the system.

\#\#\# User: Problem : Suppose that $f$ is continuous on $\\mathbb{R}$. Show that $f$ and $\\hat f$ cannot both be compactly supported unless $f\=0$.

Hint : Assume $f$ is supported in \[0,1/2]. Expand $f$ in a Fourier series in the interval \[\-,1], and note that as a result, f is a trigonometric polynomial.

I proved that f is trigonometric polynomial by using hint.
But, I don't know how to prove function's fourier transform cannot compactly supported function. 
Can I get some hints?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Suppose the support of $f$ is contained in $\[\-1,1],$ and $\\hat f (y) \= 0$ for $\|y\|\>N \\in \\mathbb N.$ Applying a standard Fourier series argument on $\[\-\\pi,\\pi]$ then shows

$$f(x) \= \\sum\_{\-N}^{N}\\hat f (n) e^{inx}, x \\in \[\-\\pi,\\pi].$$

Thus $f$ is a trigonometric polynomial that vanishes on $\[1,\\pi].$ But a trigonometric polynomial on $\[\-\\pi,\\pi]$ that vanishes at an infinite number of points must vanish identically. Thus $f\\equiv 0\.$

15.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Let f be a continuous function on ℝ. Which of the following statements is correct regarding f and its Fourier transform f̂?

A) If f is compactly supported, then f̂ must also be compactly supported.
B) If both f and f̂ are compactly supported, then f must be a non-zero function.
C) If f is compactly supported and f̂(y) = 0 for |y| > N, where N is a positive integer, then f must be identically zero.
D) If f is a non-zero compactly supported function, then f̂ must have infinite support.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) is incorrect because the Fourier transform of a compactly supported function generally has infinite support.
B) is incorrect because if both f and f̂ are compactly supported, f must be identically zero.
C) is correct. If f is compactly supported and f̂ vanishes outside a finite interval, f can be expressed as a finite trigonometric polynomial. Such a function that vanishes on any interval must be identically zero.
D) is incorrect because while this is generally true, it's not always the case (as shown by the zero function).

\#\#\# User: My Rails app runs fine in development mode (without caching) but in production has a hard time loading the :show view for the primary model. The log only shows SQL queries which add up to about 45ms, but the actual render time is about 15 seconds. I'm using acts\_as\_ferret and paperclip, but paperclip is only calling the after\_save loop to no action. There are only 1 or 2 users online at the time, so I'm not thinking I've got a backed up queue, but I really can't narrow down what's hogging up the site. What can I do to more precisely measure server\-side functions and see what is backing up the load time?

Things called in the :show view

* about 12 HABTM lists (types of tags, categories, etc.)
* Related videos found with acts\_as\_ferret
* HABTM comments for the videos

And that's really pretty much it. And how should I call HABTM as a Rails best practice? Right now I"m doing something like:

```
<%= @video.tags.map {|t| link_to t.name, path} %>
<%= @video.categories.map {|c| link_to c.name, path} %>
#etc....

```

I'm pretty sure there's a better way to do this, and I'm open to suggestion

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Here are a few tools to really pinpoint bottlenecks:

1. <http://newrelic.com/>
will analyze things like db query time and ruby execution time on the server side
2. <http://developer.yahoo.com/yslow/>
will analyze things like response time, render time, and javascript on the client side

There's not a lot of given code to run with, but there's a few things that generally help in rails `find` or `where`:

1. use `:includes` to reduce number of queries.
2. use `:select` rather than selecting all columns

Great links on the subject:  

<http://snippets.dzone.com/posts/show/2089>  

[http://www.fortytwo.gr/blog/18/9\-Essential\-Rails\-Tips](http://www.fortytwo.gr/blog/18/9-Essential-Rails-Tips)  

[http://www.engineyard.com/blog/2009/thats\-not\-a\-memory\-leak\-its\-bloat/](http://www.engineyard.com/blog/2009/thats-not-a-memory-leak-its-bloat/)

16.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: A Rails developer is experiencing slow load times in production for the :show view of their primary model, despite fast SQL query times. Which combination of tools and techniques would be most effective in identifying and addressing the performance issues?

A) Use New Relic for server-side analysis, implement eager loading with :includes, and optimize database queries with :select
B) Apply YSlow for client-side analysis, use acts_as_ferret for faster searching, and implement caching in development mode
C) Utilize both New Relic and YSlow, optimize HABTM associations, and increase server capacity
D) Implement server-side caching, use Paperclip for file attachments, and optimize JavaScript execution

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
Option A provides the most comprehensive and relevant approach to identifying and addressing the performance issues described in the question.

1. New Relic is an excellent tool for server-side analysis, which can help pinpoint bottlenecks in Ruby execution time and database queries.
2. Using :includes for eager loading can significantly reduce the number of database queries, especially useful for the multiple HABTM associations mentioned in the question.
3. Optimizing database queries with :select allows for retrieving only necessary columns, reducing data transfer and processing time.

Option B is partially correct with YSlow, but misses the crucial server-side analysis. Acts_as_ferret and development mode caching are not directly relevant to the production issue.

Option C includes good tools but doesn't address specific optimization techniques. Increasing server capacity should be a last resort after optimization attempts.

Option D focuses on techniques that are not directly related to the described problem, such as Paperclip which was mentioned as not being the cause of the slowdown.

\#\#\# User: General proposals
-----------------

The main problem I see in more general proposals is that each follower is interested in a subset of the proposal and vote for the example questions that deal with the subset. It causes proposals to have **many followers, but not enough good example questions**. For example:

* **[Pets](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/5489/pets)** \- 63 followers, 1 on\-topic, 1 off\-topic.
* **[Languages](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/16613/languages)** \- 89 followers, 1 on\-topic, 3 off\-topic.
* **[Biology](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/12502/biology)** \- 103 followers, 4 on\-topic, 3 off\-topic.

---

Specific proposals
------------------

Some specific proposals tend to slowly decay. For example:

* **[Guitars](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/6320/guitars)** \- subset of music or musicians.
* **[Bicycles](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/2305/bicycles)** \- subset of sports.

They both have a worrying visits and questions rate. There are **many highly voted merge suggestion discussions** that have been open for a while now, but still nothing gets done ([this](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/205/merging-all-music-proposals),[this](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/22/merge-sports-proposals),[this](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/88/merge-with-the-great-outdoors) \& [this](https://area51.meta.stackexchange.com/questions/83/game-specific-sites)).

---

Should we fine\-tune the rules in order to **define proposals and attract followers faster**? Should we set rules that state **when proposals get merged**?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The community coordinators have made it clear that questions generally should not be migrated to a site that is in beta for several reasons:

* The site may not survive beta. What happens to those questions that were on SO if the PM site dies?
* The migrated questions may affect the organic growth and direction of the new site. Early questions on a beta determine the site's topic and direction for a long time.
* Questions may not be tagged correctly, as ChrisF pointed out. Each question must be weighted individually.

Additionally, there is not enough traffic on the PMSE site because it's still new. However, the growth is looking good. The number of referring sites is increasing, which means that the site will eventually be easier to find in search engines. 

It takes time to build a good site, so the best approach is to let the site grow on it's own, and once it's purpose is more established by the community, then we can decide if we really want to migrate any questions.

Question: What is the primary reason given for not migrating questions from established Stack Exchange sites to beta sites?

A) Beta sites have too few followers to handle migrated questions
B) Migrated questions may affect the organic growth and direction of the new site
C) Beta sites lack experienced moderators to manage migrated content
D) Migrating questions reduces traffic on the original site

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The documentation states that "The migrated questions may affect the organic growth and direction of the new site. Early questions on a beta determine the site's topic and direction for a long time." This directly corresponds to option B. While the other options may seem plausible, they are not explicitly mentioned as primary reasons in the given text. The focus is on allowing beta sites to develop their own identity and direction without interference from migrated content.

\#\#\# User: Uhy can you add a user to a group with `usermod`, but you cant remove a user from a group with `usermod`? Am I wrong?

I got a user I want to remove from the `sudo` group. I put this user in with `usermod`, now I have to use `deluser` to remove the user from the group?

On a test box, I ran `sudo usermod -G "" user` (bad advice form some thread I read) which removed all the groups, glad I didn't run that on the server.

From the man page, I see a `-W` option that mentions removing a list of `gids`. Are `gids` groups?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Although I wouldn't necessarily recommend it, you can in fact remove a user from a supplementary group with `usermod` \- by passing a list of *groups to keep* to the `-G` command. From `man usermod`:

> ```
>    -G, --groups GROUP1[,GROUP2,...[,GROUPN]]]
>        .
>        .
>        .
> 
>        If the user is currently a member of a group which is not listed,
>        the user will be removed from the group. This behaviour can be
>        changed via the -a option, which appends the user to the current
>        supplementary group list.
> 
> ```

Ex.

```
$ id testuser
uid=1001(testuser) gid=1001(testuser) groups=1001(testuser),27(sudo),33(www-data),100(users)

$ sudo usermod -G users,www-data testuser

$ id testuser
uid=1001(testuser) gid=1001(testuser) groups=1001(testuser),33(www-data),100(users)

```

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A system administrator wants to remove a user named "john" from the "sudo" group while keeping him in the "users" and "developers" groups. Which of the following commands will accomplish this task?

A) sudo usermod -G users,developers john
B) sudo usermod -R sudo john
C) sudo deluser john sudo
D) sudo usermod -W sudo john

Correct Answer: A

Explanation:
A) This is the correct answer. The usermod command with the -G option allows you to specify a complete list of supplementary groups. By listing only "users" and "developers", john will be removed from all other groups, including "sudo".

B) This is incorrect. The -R option doesn't exist for usermod.

C) While this command would work to remove john from the sudo group, it's not using usermod as specified in the question.

D) This is incorrect. The -W option mentioned in the question is not a valid option for usermod in this context. It was a misunderstanding in the original question.

The key point is that usermod -G without the -a option will set the user's supplementary groups to exactly those listed, effectively removing the user from any groups not specified.

What is the name for this alphabet/system? Is it a universal system, or does every language have their own "version" of it?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is a universal (more or less) system for recording human speech sounds.  

It's called the [International Phonetic Alphabet](http://westonruter.github.io/ipa-chart/keyboard/), or IPA.   (Note: That's *Phonetic*, **not** *Phonemic*.)  

This contains all the sounds that occur in any human language.  

Naturally, no human language has all of them.  

No human language even has most of them.

Individual languages use only some of those sounds, and representations of words in individual languages use a special selection of these symbols \-\- different for every language \-\- called "phonemes". Usually the symbols used are taken from the IPA, but they represent only the sounds and their distribution and pronunciation **in that language**.

For instance, [this is the American English phonemic system](http://www.umich.edu/~jlawler/modestproposal.pdf), from [Kenyon and Knott](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenyon_and_Knott).

English dictionaries published in the United States normally don't use phonemic pronunciation, preferring the system invented by Noah Webster, based on spelling instead of phonetics. Webster was a spelling reformer, and believed that the traditional English spelling could be used to indicate phonetics. He was wrong, but that hasn't influenced American dictionaries.

English dictionaries published elsewhere, or bilingual dictionaries, or dictionaries intended for language learners, normally do use standard phonemic transcription. If you have a bilingual dictionary, look at the pronunciations in the English part; they will normally use either the system of Kenyon and Knott (American) or a system of [RP (UK)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_pronunciation), which has some differences from American. This is because English speakers normally pay no attention to the pronunciations in the English part, but English learners do, and they need accuracy.

The example cited

> `\pȯrt-ˈman-(ˌ)tō\`

is the style used by Merriam\-Webster, based on the original nonphonemic transcription.  

In Kenyon and Knott's system, it would be

> `/portmænto/`

and in RP it would be

> `/poətmæntəʊ/`

Regardless of what the Wikipedia entry above says, the M\-W system is **not** phonemic.

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following statements about phonetic representation systems is most accurate?

A) The International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) is a language-specific system used only for English pronunciation.

B) Merriam-Webster dictionaries use a phonemic transcription system based on the IPA.

C) The pronunciation guide used in American dictionaries is typically based on Noah Webster's spelling-based system rather than phonetic accuracy.

D) All English dictionaries worldwide use the same standardized phonetic representation system.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because the IPA is a universal system for recording human speech sounds across all languages, not just English.

B is incorrect because Merriam-Webster dictionaries use a non-phonemic transcription style based on Noah Webster's system, not the IPA or a strictly phonemic system.

C is correct. The passage states that "English dictionaries published in the United States normally don't use phonemic pronunciation, preferring the system invented by Noah Webster, based on spelling instead of phonetics."

D is incorrect because the passage indicates that different English dictionaries use different systems. American dictionaries often use Webster's system, while dictionaries published elsewhere may use standard phonemic transcription or other systems.

\#\#\# User: What is the best definition of Geographical Information Systems?

Has the definition changed at all since I was taught it 10yrs back?
The technology has changed a lot and it is more powerful than it used to be, but has that changed the overall definition of what it is? 

e.g. Is stuff like [Augmented Reality](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augmented_reality) a separate discipline altogether, or does it also merge into the world of GIS?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: My definition of GIS is... 

Using a map to answer a question.

When an understanding of the system has been developed that allows the use of the data and interface provided, to a point that users can answer questions and relate locational information to everyday tasks the system has become usable. 

GIS "IS" to each user what best answers a locational problem for them. (It could be that if a business is paying for the system then it would "need" to be a business problem). However there are many non\-business problems that can be answered that could be considered perks or job benefits. These only add to the understanding and use of locational information (GIS) in the general public. In other words IMHO limiting the use of the information only limits the understanding of GIS.

Part of the understanding and use is that there needs to be a buy\-in or time investment from some segment of the users that collects, updates, or otherwise changes data to add either accuracy, additional information, or currency to complete the cycle of use. 

The accuracy and currency of the data can take priority over the changes and usefullness of the interface only for a short time. 

The changes and enhancements to the interface need to take into account segments of users and possibly even be developed for small sets of users and groups. While making access constraints and data availablity to user groups a priority.

C) GIS is a system that uses maps to answer questions, integrating data collection, analysis, and user interface to solve locational problems for various users, while requiring ongoing data updates and interface improvements.

D) GIS is primarily focused on developing advanced technologies like Augmented Reality for geographical visualization.

Option A is too limited, focusing only on map creation and data storage. 

Option B restricts GIS to business applications, which the documentation explicitly warns against.

Option D overemphasizes new technologies like Augmented Reality, which may be related to GIS but are not central to its core definition.

The correct answer captures the essence of GIS as a tool for solving locational problems, its adaptability to different user needs, and the cyclical nature of data improvement and system usability.

\#\#\# User: Calculate $\\displaystyle \\int ^{\\infty}\_{0}\\frac{x^a}{(x\+b)^2}\\mathrm{d}x$ where $\|a\|\<1$ and $b\>0$.

What I thought is taking almost a sphere without a slice on positive real axis.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: $x^a$ has a branch line from $0$ to $\\infty$. Consider the contour integral from $\\infty$ to $0$ below the branch, it will be $\-e^{2\\pi i a}\\int\_0^\\infty dx \\frac{x^a}{(x\+b)}$ then continue the contour from $0$ to $\\infty$ above the contour, which is simply $\\int\_0^\\infty dx \\frac{x^a}{(x\+b)}$. The total contour integral is then

$\\oint dx \\frac{x^a}{(x\+b)} \= (1\-e^{2\\pi i a})\\int\_0^\\infty dx \\frac{x^a}{(x\+b)}$.

The contour can also be closed around the double pole at $\-b$, yielding $\\oint dx \\frac{x^a}{(x\+b)} \= \-2\\pi i a e^{\\pi i a}b^{a\-1}$.

Equating the 2 contour integrals yields $\\int\_0^\\infty dx \\frac{x^a}{(x\+b)} \= \\pi\\frac{a b^{a\-1}}{Sin(\\pi a)}$.

23.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Given the integral $I = \int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^a}{(x+b)^2}dx$, where $|a|<1$ and $b>0$, which of the following statements is correct?

A) The integral can be directly evaluated using the result $\int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^a}{(x+b)}dx = \pi\frac{a b^{a-1}}{Sin(\pi a)}$

B) The integral equals $\pi\frac{a(a-1) b^{a-2}}{Sin(\pi a)}$

C) The integral can be evaluated by differentiating $\int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^a}{(x+b)}dx$ with respect to $b$

D) The integral diverges for all values of $a$ in the given range

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) is incorrect because the given result is for $\frac{x^a}{(x+b)}$, not $\frac{x^a}{(x+b)^2}$.
B) is incorrect. While this looks like it could be the answer if we differentiated the given result with respect to $b$, it's not quite right.
C) is correct. We can use the result $\int_0^{\infty} \frac{x^a}{(x+b)}dx = \pi\frac{a b^{a-1}}{Sin(\pi a)}$ and differentiate both sides with respect to $b$ to get our desired integral. This is because $\frac{d}{db}\frac{1}{x+b} = -\frac{1}{(x+b)^2}$.
D) is incorrect. The integral converges for $|a|<1$ and $b>0$.

\#\#\# User: I'm trying to prove following equation with induction:

$$
\\sum\_{k\=1}^{2n\-1} (\-1\)^{k\-1}(k\-1\)(k\+1\) \= 2n^2 \- n \- 1
\\\\\~\~\\\\
$$

First step is the base case, which for $ n \= 1$ is true.

$$
(\-1\)^{0}(0\)(2\) \= 0 \= 2(1\)^2\-1\-1
$$

Then we can assume that the equation is true for $n$, therefore we want to prove that it's also the case for $n\+1$

$$
\\sum\_{k\=1}^{2(n\+1\)\-1} (\-1\)^{k\-1}(k\-1\)(k\+1\) \= \\\\ (\\sum\_{k\=1}^{2n\-1} (\-1\)^{k\-1}(k\-1\)(k\+1\) ) \+ (\-1\)^{2(n\+1\)\-1}(2(n\+1\)\-2\)(2(n\+1\))
$$

That means for the right side of the equation:

$$
2n^2\-n\-1 \+ (\-1\)^{2(n\+1\)\-1}(2(n\+1\)\-2\)(2(n\+1\))
$$

Removing the brackets results in:
$$
2n^2\-n\-1\+(\-1\)^{2n}(2n)(2n\+2\) \= \\\\\~\\\\2n^2\-n\-1\+(\-1\)^{2n}(4n^2\+4n)
$$

I'm not sure if I am allowed to make an assumption, but I did: 

$$
\\forall n \\epsilon \\mathbb{N} :(\-1\)^{2n} \= 1
$$
Since it's equivalent to:
$$
((\-1\)^n)^2 \= ((\-1\)^2\)^n
$$

By replacing it with $1$, the last step is summing it up:
$$
6n^2\+3n\-1
$$

Which is wrong ... Am I allowed to make the assumption? And where did I make the mistake? (Hint preferred) 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You have two different contexts of $A$\-algebra in the literature. Both give an external definition of the situation $A\\subset\_{subring}B$. All depends on the context. 

A) The first one (the most spread and your case) is that $B$ is a $A$\-module with commutation of the multiplications i.e. for all $a\\in A$ and $b\_i\\in B$, one has the identities (associativity w.r.t. to scaling) 
$$
a(b\_1b\_2\))\=(ab\_1\)b\_2\=b\_1(ab\_2\)
$$

Here, "finitely generated as a $A$ algebra" means that there exists a finite set $F\\subset B$ such that the smallest $B\_1$ for which  

$$
A\\cup F\\subset\_{subring}B\_1\\subset\_{subring}B
$$
is precisely $B$. 

From this, you see that **$B$ is finitely generated as a $A$\-module (FGM)** means that it exists $F\=\\{f\_1,f\_2,\\cdots f\_n\\}\\subset B$, such that for all $b\\in B$ we have a decomposition 
$$
b\=\\sum\_{i\=1}^n a\_if\_i
$$
with $a\_i\\in A$.

And **$B$ is finitely generated as a $A$\-algebra (FGA)** means that it exists 
$F\=\\{f\_1,f\_2,\\cdots f\_n\\}\\subset B$, such that for all $b\\in B$ we have a decomposition 
$$
b\=\\sum\_{\\alpha\\in \\mathbb{N}^F} a\_\\alpha F^\\alpha
$$
where $\\alpha$ is a (weight) mapping $F\\to \\mathbb{N}$ i.e. 
$\\alpha(f\_i)\=\\alpha\_i$ and $F^\\alpha\=f\_1^{\\alpha\_1}\\cdots f\_n^{\\alpha\_n}$ (multiindex notation) and $a\_\\alpha\\in A$. 

So (FGM) implies (FGA). 

For the converse, you need to extend $F$ with the products of powers of the $f\_i$, but remaining finite. There the condition that $B$ is integral has to be used. In view of \[1], for all $i\\in I$, one can write 
$$
f\_i^{d\_i}\=\\sum\_{k\=0}^{d\_i\-1}a\_k\\,f\_i^k
$$
this proves that every $F^\\alpha$ can be written as a $A$\-linear combination of the $F^\\beta$ with $\\beta\_i\< d\_i$ for all $i$. But those $F^\\beta$ are in finite number. So $B$ is (FGM). 

B) In the second one, we have $B$ is a $A$\-bimodule and one has, still for all $a\\in A$ and for all $b\_i\\in B$ (associativity w.r.t. scalings) 
$$
a(b\_1b\_2\)\=(ab\_1\)b\_2\\ ;\\ b\_1(ab\_2\)\=(b\_1a)b\_2\\ ;\\ (b\_1b\_2\)a\=b\_1(b\_2a)
$$
\[1] wikipedia page <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral_element>

27.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Consider a ring A and its extension B, where B is integral over A. Which of the following statements is true regarding the relationship between B being finitely generated as an A-module (FGM) and B being finitely generated as an A-algebra (FGA)?

A) FGM always implies FGA, but FGA does not necessarily imply FGM.

B) FGA always implies FGM, but FGM does not necessarily imply FGA.

C) FGM and FGA are equivalent conditions when B is integral over A.

D) FGM and FGA are independent conditions and neither implies the other, even when B is integral over A.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: When B is integral over A, FGM (finitely generated as an A-module) and FGA (finitely generated as an A-algebra) are equivalent conditions. 

FGM implies FGA because any finite set of module generators will also generate B as an A-algebra. 

For the converse (FGA implies FGM), we use the fact that B is integral over A. If B is FGA with generators {f₁, ..., fₙ}, then for each fᵢ, there exists a monic polynomial with coefficients in A that fᵢ satisfies. This allows us to express any power of fᵢ as an A-linear combination of lower powers, bounded by the degree of its minimal polynomial. Consequently, any element of B can be expressed as an A-linear combination of products of the generators with bounded exponents, which forms a finite set. Thus, B is also FGM.

This equivalence holds specifically when B is integral over A, which is a crucial condition for the implication from FGA to FGM.

\#\#\# User: I want to create a template using the "Print Composer" from my layers loaded in QGIS 2\.18\.7 (Las Palmas). The problem is that it seems the map element is not "synchronized" with the map view. For instance, if I zoom\-in on the map view, I want the map element on the template also being automatically updated with the zoom. 

Another problem related to this is that I don't know how to display the selected features in the template: 
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Tv6bk.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Tv6bk.jpg)

Is there any way of updating the map template automatically?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: With a little help from **Python**, we could create a function which refreshes your composer map each time the canvas extent (from the main window) has changed. In otherwords, whenever you pan or zoom in/out of the canvas, the composer map will also update. You can type the following code into the **Python Console**:

```
def update_composer():
    active_Composer = iface.activeComposers()
    canvas = iface.mapCanvas()
    composer = active_Composer[0]
    composition = composer.composition()
    maps = [item for item in composition.items() if item.type() == QgsComposerItem.ComposerMap and item.scene()]
    composer_map = maps[0]
    moveX = composer_map.extent().center().x()-canvas.extent().center().x()
    moveY = composer_map.extent().center().y()-canvas.extent().center().y()
    unitCon = composer_map.mapUnitsToMM()
    composer_map.moveContent(-moveX * unitCon, moveY * unitCon)
    composer_map.setNewScale(canvas.scale())

iface.mapCanvas().extentsChanged.connect(update_composer)

```

---

*Credit to the author Ed B for his plugin: [Sync Composer With Map](https://github.com/boesiii/synccomposerwithmap) of which this code was based upon (you can download/install this plugin from the menubar:* `Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins...`).

28.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In QGIS 2.18.7, a user wants to automatically update the map template in Print Composer when changes are made to the main map canvas. Which of the following Python code snippets would correctly implement this functionality?

A) 
```python
def update_composer():
    composer = iface.activeComposers()[0]
    canvas = iface.mapCanvas()
    composer.refreshItems()
    
iface.mapCanvas().extentsChanged.connect(update_composer)
```

B)
```python
def update_composer():
    active_Composer = iface.activeComposers()
    canvas = iface.mapCanvas()
    composer = active_Composer[0]
    composition = composer.composition()
    maps = [item for item in composition.items() if item.type() == QgsComposerItem.ComposerMap and item.scene()]
    composer_map = maps[0]
    moveX = composer_map.extent().center().x()-canvas.extent().center().x()
    moveY = composer_map.extent().center().y()-canvas.extent().center().y()
    unitCon = composer_map.mapUnitsToMM()
    composer_map.moveContent(-moveX * unitCon, moveY * unitCon)
    composer_map.setNewScale(canvas.scale())

iface.mapCanvas().extentsChanged.connect(update_composer)
```

C)
```python
def update_composer():
    composer = iface.activeComposers()[0]
    canvas = iface.mapCanvas()
    composer.composition().refreshItems()
    composer.updateItem()

iface.mapCanvas().scaleChanged.connect(update_composer)
```

D)
```python
def update_composer():
    composer = iface.activeComposers()[0]
    canvas = iface.mapCanvas()
    composer_map = composer.composition().getComposerMapById(0)
    composer_map.zoomToExtent(canvas.extent())

iface.mapCanvas().panChanged.connect(update_composer)
```

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B because it provides the most comprehensive solution to synchronize the Print Composer map with the main map canvas. This code snippet:

1. Retrieves the active composer and canvas
2. Identifies the composer map item
3. Calculates the difference in position between the composer map and canvas
4. Adjusts the content position of the composer map
5. Updates the scale of the composer map to match the canvas
6. Connects the function to the extentsChanged signal of the map canvas

Options A, C, and D are incomplete or incorrect approaches that don't properly synchronize all aspects of the map (position, scale, and extent) or don't use the correct signals and methods to achieve the desired result.

Here's a multi-form question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: You are developing a complex desktop application using the MVC pattern. The main controller is becoming bloated with numerous methods and dependencies. Which of the following approaches would be the most effective way to address this issue while maintaining good design principles?

A) Keep all logic in the main controller, but split it into multiple files using partial classes to improve code organization.

B) Create multiple smaller controllers, each responsible for a specific subset of functionality, and have them communicate through a façade pattern.

C) Move all complex logic into the model, leaving only basic input handling in the controller.

D) Implement a single large service class that handles all business logic, accessed by the controller through dependency injection.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B is the most effective approach in this scenario. By creating multiple smaller controllers, each responsible for a specific subset of functionality, you adhere to the Single Responsibility Principle and keep classes focused and manageable. The façade pattern allows for a clean interface between these controllers, maintaining a organized structure. This approach addresses the issue of the bloated main controller while also allowing for easier maintenance and scalability.

Option A doesn't solve the underlying issue of complexity and violates the Single Responsibility Principle. Option C misuses the MVC pattern by putting too much logic in the model. Option D creates another large, complex class, which doesn't solve the original problem and could lead to similar issues in the future.

\#\#\# User: When I perform an ls command in my aws ec2 server, I am getting the correct list of files which I need, but for some reason the `user@ip:directory/folder` is showing on the last line of my results? Is there any way to remove this? 

I am parsing some dates from a list of files to process later, but this `user@ip:directory/folder` is showing up in the list and causing issues.

Example:
My directory is `documents/files`
within files there are 

```
20191214.txt
20191215.txt
20191216.txt

```

I run the command `aws s3 ls documents/files`

and the result is

```
20191214.txt
20191215.txt
20191216.txt
user@ip:documents/files

```

Is there any way to remove `user@ip:documents/files` from my list of results? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Assuming tab\-delimited data:

```none
$ awk -F '\t' -v OFS='\t' '{ sub("-.*", "", $9); print }' file
DRX154054       ILLUMINA        SINGLE  ChIP-seq        mm_embryonicstemcell_embryonicstemcell  Mus_musculusNone     No      ELL1    NA      NA      NA      ftp://ftp-trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/sra-instant/reads/ByExp/sra/DRX/DRX154/DRX154054/
DRX154053       ILLUMINA        SINGLE  ChIP-seq        mm_embryonicstemcell_embryonicstemcell  Mus_musculusNone     No      ELL2    NA      NA      NA      ftp://ftp-trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/sra-instant/reads/ByExp/sra/DRX/DRX154/DRX154053/
ERX3608304      ILLUMINA        SINGLE  ChIP-Seq        mm_Unknown_Unknown      Mus_musculus    None    No  EP1      NA      NA      NA      ftp://ftp-trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/sra-instant/reads/ByExp/sra/ERX/ERX360/ERX3608304/
DRX154052       ILLUMINA        SINGLE  ChIP-seq        mm_embryonicstemcell_embryonicstemcell  Mus_musculusNone     No      DNMT3A  NA      NA      NA      ftp://ftp-trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/sra-instant/reads/ByExp/sra/DRX/DRX154/DRX154052/

```

This simply applies a substitution to the 9th field that removes everything from the first dash character onwards in that field. The modified data is then printed.

The regular expression `-.*` will match from the first `-` onwards (literally "match a `-` followed by zero or more of any character"), and using this with `sub()` and an empty replacement string on the 9th field removes all text that matches from that field. Note that we don't need to use `gsub()` here as we will only ever have to do the replacement once per input line.

Since we modify one of the fields, we also have to make sure that the output field separator (`OFS`) is set to a tab character, otherwise we'll get space\-separated fields in the output. You could obviously have done that with a `BEGIN` block as well:

```none
awk 'BEGIN { OFS=FS="\t" } { sub("-.*", "", $9); print }' file

```

32.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are working with a tab-delimited file containing genomic data. The 9th field of each line contains an identifier followed by additional information after a dash (-). You want to remove everything after and including the dash in the 9th field. Which AWK command would accomplish this task?

A) awk -F '\t' '{ sub("-.*", "", $9); print }' file

B) awk -F '\t' -v OFS='\t' '{ gsub("-.*", "", $9); print }' file

C) awk 'BEGIN { OFS=FS="\t" } { sub("-.*", "", $9); print }' file

D) awk -F '\t' -v OFS='\t' '{ sub("-.*", "", $9); print }' file

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:
A) This option is close but missing the OFS setting, which is crucial for maintaining tab-delimited output.
B) This uses gsub() instead of sub(), which is unnecessary as we only need to perform the substitution once per line.
C) While this would work, it's not the exact syntax provided in the top answer.
D) This is the correct answer as it matches the syntax in the top answer. It sets both input and output field separators to tabs (-F '\t' -v OFS='\t'), uses sub() to remove everything from the dash onwards in the 9th field, and prints the result.

The key elements here are:
1. Setting input and output field separators to tabs
2. Using sub() for a one-time substitution per line
3. Applying the substitution only to the 9th field ($9)
4. Printing the modified line

This command will effectively remove the unwanted part of the identifier while maintaining the tab-delimited structure of the file.

\#\#\# User: I'm looking for examples of phrases \& sentences whose meaning changes depending on the tone of voice used.

For example,

'Follow me.' (Said with a falling tone) would be understood as a command.

'Follow me?' (Said with a rising tone) would be understood as a question (ie. do you understand me?)

The longer and more grammatically correct the better!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Practically all sentences have different meanings, or at least different intrepretations, when spoken with different stress and intonation patterns. Every native speaker realizes this. 

Most [Garden Path sentences](http://www.umich.edu/~jlawler/gardenpath.pdf), for instance, while disturbingly difficult to process in written form, pose no troubles at all in speech, because stress and intonation differentiates them effectively. Some examples:

* *The man who hunts ducks out on weekends*.
* *The dog that I had really loved bones.*

English orthography does not represent stress or intonation in any consistent way, and therefore has to resort to all kinds of artificial and ill\-understood subterfuges, like [punctuation](http://www.umich.edu/~jlawler/IELL-Punctuation.pdf), to try to represent at least a bit of it. The result is as you see.

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between spoken and written English, particularly in terms of conveying meaning through intonation and stress?

A) Written English is superior to spoken English in conveying nuanced meanings due to its use of punctuation.

B) Spoken English relies solely on word choice to convey meaning, while written English uses punctuation for clarity.

C) Garden Path sentences are equally challenging to understand in both spoken and written forms.

D) Spoken English can effectively convey different meanings through intonation and stress, which written English struggles to represent accurately.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. The passage emphasizes that spoken English can easily convey different meanings through intonation and stress patterns, which are natural for native speakers to interpret. In contrast, written English lacks consistent ways to represent these important vocal cues, often relying on imperfect methods like punctuation to attempt to capture some of this nuance. 

Option A is incorrect because the passage suggests that written English is actually inferior in conveying these nuanced meanings. 

Option B is wrong as it ignores the crucial role of intonation and stress in spoken language, which the passage highlights.

Option C contradicts the information given, which states that Garden Path sentences are much easier to understand when spoken due to stress and intonation cues.

Option D accurately summarizes the main point of the passage regarding the strengths of spoken English and the limitations of written English in conveying meaning through intonation and stress.

\#\#\# User: i am wondering if there is a complete solution for the equation $a^2\+pb^2\-2c^2\-2kcd\+(p\+k^2\)d^2\=0$ in which $a,b,c,d,k$ are integer(not all zero) and $p$ is odd prime. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'm not getting much 2\-adic information for this one, but it should be easy enough to check all solutions mod 8 and mod 16 and see what happens.

To restrict anything, one property requires $p \\equiv \\pm 3 \\pmod 8$ and the other requires $p \\equiv 3 \\pmod 4\.$ Put them together, when $$p \\equiv 3 \\pmod 8 $$ and
$$ p \| k, $$
then all four of your letters $$ a,b,c,d \= 0\.$$
The proof uses two flavors of anisotropy for binaries. The assumption is that at least one of
$ a,b,c,d $ is nonzero and $\\gcd(a,b,c,d) \= 1\.$
 First we have forced 
$a^2 \- 2 c^2 \\equiv 0 \\pmod p,$ so $a,c \\equiv 0 \\pmod p$ as $(2 \| p) \= \-1\.$ But then
$ p b^2 \+ p d^2 \\equiv 0 \\pmod {p^2},$ or
 $ b^2 \+ d^2 \\equiv 0 \\pmod p,$ so $b,d \\equiv 0 \\pmod p$ as $(\-1 \| p) \= \-1\.$ So 
 $ p \| \\gcd(a,b,c,d)$ contrary to assumption.

Otherwise, given a fixed $(p,k)$ once you have a nontrivial solution you get infinitely many
using automorphs of the indefinite part in variables $(c,d).$ That is, there may be many parametrized families of solutions of one type or another. But you can figure some of those out with a computer algebra system more easily than I can by hand.

The next interesting case is when $12 k^2 \+ 8p$ is a square, which means that the binary form 
$T(c,d)\=2c^2\+2kcd\-(p\+k^2\)d^2$ factors. So $3 k^2 \+ 2p$ is a square, which is not possible for even $k,$ so $k$ is odd and $2p \\equiv 6 \\pmod 8,$ or $p \\equiv \-1 \\pmod 4\.$ Unless $p\=3$ we also need 
 $p \\equiv \-1 \\pmod 3,$ or $p \\equiv \-1 \\equiv 11 \\pmod {12}.$

For example, with $p\=11, k\=1,3 k^2 \+ 2p \= 25, p \+ k^2 \= 12,$ we have
$$ a^2\+11b^2\-2c^2\-2cd\+12d^2 \= a^2\+11b^2\-2(c\-2d)(c\+3d).$$
The value of the factorization is that we can take, for instance, $c \= 2 d \+ 1, c \+ 3 d \= 5 d \+ 1,$ and
$$ a^2\+11b^2\-2(5d\+1\) \= 0\.$$ Now $a^2 \+ 11 b^2$ is not even unless it is also 
divisible by $4\.$ We also need $ a^2 \\equiv b^2 \\equiv 1 \\pmod 5\.$ Put them together, we have a parametrized solution of sorts, with $$ a \\equiv 1,4 \\pmod 5, \\; \\; b \\equiv 1,4 \\pmod 5, \\; \\; a \\equiv b \\pmod 2$$ take $c \= 2 d \+ 1$ and
$$ d \= \\frac{ a^2\+11b^2\-2}{10}.$$

35.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Consider the Diophantine equation $a^2+11b^2-2c^2-2cd+12d^2=0$, where $a,b,c,d$ are integers. Which of the following statements is true about the solutions to this equation?

A) The equation has no non-trivial integer solutions.

B) If $c = 2d + 1$, then $a$ and $b$ must be even.

C) There exist infinitely many solutions where $a \equiv 1 \text{ or } 4 \pmod{5}$, $b \equiv 1 \text{ or } 4 \pmod{5}$, and $a \equiv b \pmod{2}$.

D) The equation only has solutions when $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ are all multiples of 11.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The equation can be rewritten as $a^2+11b^2-2(c-2d)(c+3d)=0$. When $c = 2d + 1$, we get $a^2+11b^2-2(5d+1)=0$. The documentation shows that there are infinitely many solutions satisfying the conditions in option C, where $a \equiv 1 \text{ or } 4 \pmod{5}$, $b \equiv 1 \text{ or } 4 \pmod{5}$, $a \equiv b \pmod{2}$, and $d = \frac{a^2+11b^2-2}{10}$. Options A and D are incorrect as they contradict the existence of these solutions. Option B is false because $a$ and $b$ can be odd (when they are both congruent to 1 or both congruent to 4 modulo 5).
